Hi Dodd, don't you think its time for another interview with Peter Beck to discuss the Neutron?

The world is so different now.  Imagine in 1990 what would have happened if someone represented a huge tech company while just sitting in a chair with his arms slumped down wearing a t-shirt.   Oh, no, that wouldn't have worked.  Even if it were possible to video conference, you'd still have to be in a good suit at the end of a conference room table keeping up that professional experience.   So nice that we can just focus on the task at hand and try to get down to competence instead of just appearance now.  The tech guys running the show is the new world.

Beck didn’t really reveal much of anything. And given he’s at best a 2nd in space race - what secrets does he think are so precious? It’s almost guarantee that he learned SpaceX lessons and his design will likely be similar to falcon 9, unless SpaceX missed some major optimization... not a very likely scenario.

3 strategic mistakes so far by Beck:

1. Betting on low manufacturing frequency of 1st stages and engines. It’s bad/expensive for testing phase, bad for high demand growth phase

2. Making rocket too wide for roads - restricts severely launch locations, where manufacturing is, where talent is.

3. Not looking ahead to full reusability. By the time he’ ready with new rocket, it will be obsolete and he will have to eat another heat

They need to focus on something other than rockets. What about space hardware? We need space hardware companies. Starship will dominate the market such that no company like Rocket Lab can possibly stand a chance. There’s no point. It is IMPOSSIBLE for them to win this. SpaceX will essentially have a monopoly on rockets with Starship. They are building the jet engine of commercial airliners.

Other Space companies MUST start competing with starship specs IMMEDIATELY.

Pretty much everyone is saying starship doesn’t make everything else obsolete, but they clearly aren’t looking at it from a business perspective. Jumbo jet is to biplane as Starship is to all other rockets.

These companies need to figure this the f out.

Once Starship is fully operational, they can put like 300-400 tons into orbit each day all for a fraction of the cost of literally any other rocket.

I personally think that Australia and New Zealand should work together to contract Rocket Lab with just as favourable terms as if the US wanted to use Rocket Lab's Neutron for human spaceflight.
It would give the small guys some independence with their own program to get access to space. It would be a cost effective solution just as NASA has found using Space X's crew dragon.
And even better because of Rocket Lab's dual ties this can still employ locals to manage the launches whether launching from NZ or Australia.
It just makes it all possible due to the fact that Rocket lab is not constrained to only manufacturing in the USA (they can work out if it is more economical to ship it from USA or make it in NZ for example.)

The Neutron projected 8,000 kg (17,600 lb) LEO lift seems a bit low for a manned flight.  Even the Soyuz M, a tiny spacecraft, has a launch mass 7,150 kg (15,760 lb).  Dragon 2,  CST-100 Starliner, Dream Chaser and Orion all have much greater launch mass than the Neutron has lift.
Workhorse Russian approach vs  American Mega tech innovation is sort of the vibe I'm getting.

Oooo, less engines is better because less can go wrong. Yeah sure Space X is using some 28 raptors, but then you gotta remember it's like 28 smaller engines pushing a whole Starship and the Booster into space so it's needed. And from the Falcon 9 landings, you can see that they don't need to use every engine to get it to land again. And Elon atm is also figuring out the perfect number for Starship, and so far it's all 3 with 1 or 2 cutting out dependent on how fast the landing is. Same goes for the Booster, probably needing 10-15 to get it to land again

Thank you to both Tim Dodd and Peter Beck for this revealing and interesting discussion. I'm rooting for the Neutron development team; the concept looks very promising.

@Everyday Astronaut: Tim, I see that i partnership between Rocket Lab and Masten Space System — the specialist in propulsive rocket landing— a really good idea. Point-to-point landing would be really nice. Other than shipping products from A to B, just imagine sending the new rockets from the manufacturing site, to the mission launch site, doing the standard maintenance to be relaunched for the next mission. WoW! that would enable a launch from almost any country in the world interested in sending critical protected technology from their own countries.

It looks he is going in a similar Direction as SpaceX, but not a carbon copy,  that's a good thing, I think I heard Elon Musk mention  that if he knew then, what he knows now, the Falcon 9 would have been very different.
$VACQ gang wya? 🔥

I love what Peter Beck is doing with electron from a "first principles" perspective, but I can't help but feel that Rocket Lab is skating to where the puck was with Neutron. At this point there has been a very cost effective solution in Falcon 9 for a decade, which is in some sense "old space" already.

You asked all the right questions but beyond something fairly magical to reduce the payload penalty (and therefore cost to fly), I don't see what this offers over what Falcon 9 offers *now*.

Whilst I personally am fine with multiple competing companies, I haven't (yet) seen any kind of USP that gets this off the ground.
Great interview Tim!  Drone ship or return to launch site!?!?!  Next time 😉

Totally sounds like a dedicated landing engine is on the cards, if you can get the weight back by having fewer primary engines you could spend that weight on a calibrated landing engine that could have the landing thrust in the middle of the throttle rather than at the lower end which would be safer as low throttle can lead to a stall, could also potentially be used as a reserve engine or additional engine if you wanted to lift 10 ton expendable.
28:08 fully reusable Neutron? 😳

A man who started from humble beginnings, using old washing machine bits for home made rockets. Bit of number 8 wire ingenuity (the kiwi way) and Rocket Lab was formed. A company that treats every single one of its employees properly. Super proud to have been able to photograph each launch from L11 to now.

More serious question than my previous comment: Is the main challenge with heat shields for reentry about weight?  meaning, obviously they can make something beefy enough to project an entire rocket, but it would weigh so much that the rocket could no longer do its job?  If I were thinking about this problem like a ship in the water, if I wanted to slow it down and keep waves off the bow, I'd stick a super blunt object out in front of it then the ship would be in its wake.  Could the heat shield be extended beyond the bells of engines after they've been shut off for stage separation? Maybe with some sort of kinetic design that doesn't require heavy hydraulics?  Or use the Electrons batteries to run an electric motor?

I think SpaceX is pushing their engines too far for performance for their reusability intent.  BitCoin miners under-volt their GPUs significantly to ensure they can be kept at 100% without much attention paid to maintenance (and cheap out on cooling needs and power consumption too) and also minimize failures and need for replacement or overhaul. SpaceX is doing the opposite with their Starship raptor engines as well as their rocket hulls - overclocking stuff intended to be massively reused with minimal servicing.

If you know in advance which launch of a reusable first stage will be its last one, then (by definition) that is the one it makes most sense to sell as "expendable". This provides flexibility from multiple perspectives:
- A "motivated" customer could pay more to expend a flight-proven first stage earlier (rather than on its maiden flight, as is generally assumed).
- The launch provider could simply want to phase in an upgraded first stage sooner rather than later.
- Labor limitations concerning production vs. refurbishment could make it more profitable to expend a first stage sooner rather than hire more staff.

Using a reusable first stage in expendable mode should be done opportunistically, with short(-ish) notice. The goal being to pick only the most profitable expendable opportunities, rather than have them sold on a fixed schedule.

Regarding the engines on Neutron:

Peter Beck: There could be something between those four engines [for Neutron] that you can't see... potentially. But this is a challenge, because for a launch vehicle, in my opinion now, you want the least amount of engines as possible, because the more number of engines, the more acceptance testing and the more qualification and the more of everything. So, the least number of engines is always optimal. However, when you're talking propulsive landing, then you have a particular thrust that you require for that maneuver, and that doesn't trade nicely for the smallest number of engines as possible. So, both of those constraints are polar opposite to each other from what you actually want to achieve. [But] there are some interesting trades you can make to try to optimize that.

The Neutron should be Named "Myon", because:
- The Name "Proton" is already taken
- Elektrons and Myons are both Leptons
- The Myon is much heavier then the Electron
- A Rocket after that could be called after the Lepton "Tau" (even heavier), otherwise it would be an unrelated name
